review.title: Characterizing Concept Drift
review.abstract: Most machine learning models are static, but the world is dynamic, and increasing online deployment of learned models gives increasing urgency to the development of efficient and effective mechanisms to address learning in the context of non-stationary distributions, or as it is commonly called concept drift. However, the key issue of characterizing the different types of drift that can occur has not previously been subjected to rigorous definition and analysis. In particular, while some qualitative drift categorizations have been proposed, few have been formally defined, and the quantitative descriptions required for detailed understanding of learner performance have not existed. We present the first comprehensive framework for quantitative analysis of drift. This supports the development of the first comprehensive set of formal definitions of types of concept drift. The formal definitions clarify ambiguities and identify gaps in previous definitions, giving rise to a new comprehensive taxonomy of concept drift types and a solid foundation for research into mechanisms to detect and address concept drift.

sections.heading: 5 Case study
sections.text: We have argued that our new quantitative characterizations of the concept of drift are critical to the deep understanding of drift = 2001, its impact on learning systems, the capacity of drift detection mechanisms to detect drift, the ability of drift remediation mechanisms, and our ability to develop effective mechanisms to detect and respond to drift. To support these claims, we are conducting a simple proof-of-concept study that provides significant insights that would not be possible without our quantitative measurements. To this end, we have generated synthetic data containing an abrupt drift of a given magnitude. We conducted the experiments at the MOA. We have examined the workbench that answers to this drift from the following key learners from MOA: AccuracyUpdatedEnsembles [BrzeDrizinski and Stefanowski, 2014b], AccuracytedEnsemble [Wang et al], 2003b, AccuracytedEnsemble.

sections.heading: 6 Discussion
sections.text: In this section, we explore some of the implications of our new conceptual analysis of concept errors. Many of the qualitative definitions are based on user-defined thresholds.

sections.heading: 7 Conclusion
sections.text: We have provided the first quantitative measures of key aspects of the concept of drift, laying the groundwork for a more thorough objective characterization and analysis of concept drift and concept drift algorithms, which have provided a basis for formal definitions of the many different qualitative types of drift previously identified in the literature, a process that has clarified ambiguities and identified gaps in previous definitions that we have filled by defining new terms. In some cases, these types have received implicit assumptions underlying previous work that flows are subject to drift cycles interrupted by periods of stability. We have also created a new drift type taxonomy covering all the different types of drift that have been identified. In some cases, these types have been given new names that we believe are more significant and less ambiguous than previous terminology.

Two variants of a definition by extension are possible, by type or token [Zalta, 2009]. A definition by type defines a concept as a set of vectors of X values such that any object with any vector of values in the set belongs to the concept, or equivalently, as a function X → Y Such a definition does not allow that different objects with identical attribute values might belong to different concepts. metadata.abstractText: Most machine learning models are static, but the world is dynamic, and increasing online deployment of learned models gives increasing urgency to the development of efficient and effective mechanisms to address learning in the context of non-stationary distributions, or as it is commonly called concept drift. However, the key issue of characterizing the different types of drift that can occur has not previously been subjected to rigorous definition and analysis. In particular, while some qualitative drift categorizations have been proposed, few have been formally defined, and the quantitative descriptions required for detailed understanding of learner performance have not existed.
